instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
Hi I know I posted this earlier last month but now I have two with the same issue :/
Camera not recognized. I just finished testing 2 -<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and the FaceTime works fine :/ I tried PRAM and installed a new OS X on my test drive 
Both <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> where water damaged but no where near Anything todo with camera 
one was near smc the other had near <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> I’m not sure what’s the issue also the test chassis is a 2013 air shell if they helps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
Sometimes BIOS corruption is possible on water damaged boards.
You should try known good BIOS, clean ME to discard this.
Corrupted ME region is known to cause this symptom.

Also read Piernov post at the end of this thread.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-stuck-on-progress-bar-with-applecamin.54959/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
ok I will :) thanks

after reading post he mentioned that replacing <RESISTOR>R2042</RESISTOR> Repaired the camera. I will check <RESISTOR>R2042</RESISTOR> or equivalent on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: Ok I tried replacing the above component it was in fact reading the same 8ohms I replaced it with a 0ohm 201 resistor and it’s the same issue no camera detected.  I will order a new bios chip and switch out the old one with new. I still have to try smc reset but I’m my short experience never does anything. I’m currently check the voltages and <SIGNAL>CAM_SENSOR_WAKE_L_CONN</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R4031</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R4030</RESISTOR> and L4009, L4007 to see if there’s any physical damage or liquid. I’m assuming the camera must be connected for these lines to be active I’ve also ordered a camera cable just for ease of use

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
Be aware of new BIOS chip.
Very likely they just write dump read form other board.
No clean ME region in such case; and will not serve you!!!

Once battery is removed (also charger), SMC reset is automatically done when power is applied again.
No need to bother with that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: Yes I plan to do a clean Me on the new chip I just wanted to have the old Chip in case I had a issue to swap back :) thank you for your help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
Make backup and verify if read good.
Then you can erase original chip and write it many times...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: This issue is almost ALWAYS <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, if no damage to board (and no tampering with BIOS). We repair at least one of these per week, and replacing <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> resolves issue about 90% of the time. Another thing you really need to check on these is the pins on iSight connector itself--both inside connector and external. I've had a dozen or so of these 00165 boards that actually had loose pins at the board; they just didn't have enough solder and broke free at some point. Lastly, I've seen several that had a pin very slightly lodged/stuck inside connector so it wasn't making good contact. If BIOS has been fucked with, then disregard all of this and start there!

threads.message:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: I’ve come back to this board once again I replaced BCM <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> chip cleaned me region and nothing :( I resoldered the camera connector. Is it possible that I can send the file for bios and maybe you can clean the me :/ I’ve tried but maybe I’m not doing it right. I’ll go over the pier rails again. It’s hard to diagnose:( I’ve tried many ways lastly I’m gonna try to use a external keyboard and mouse with DisplayPort out and a camera connected open the app and see if I’m getting all my signals. Last I checked all inputs where there. So I don’t know what’s going on here. It initially had some water damage on <CAPACITOR>C4030</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C4031</CAPACITOR> replaced both caps with new and <CHIP>U2030</CHIP> is no stuff

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
That chip is easy te destroy if overheat its Si die.
If camera connector is properly soldered, check if ALS sensor works at least.
If not, be sure 5V voltage arrives to connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: Ok I’ll check it. I used around 380 to solder it and it’s the same symptoms as before :/ all inputs and no change on output

threads.message: Ok yes als works I cover camera and key board lights intensify. I tried also re installing OS X and even erase ssd several time. Just in case it was a software issue :( I’m basically stuck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message:
We should have several BIOS files with clean ME posted on the forum.
Be sure to have good connections for camera lines and try another camera too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: Linux camera driver is more verbose than macOS and shows you some initialization steps in the kernel log. It may or may not help narrowing down the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no camera detected
threads.message: Check inside the camera connector to make sure no pins are pushed "up" and not making proper contact with the cable; have had a few instances of this. Also, did you buy <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> reballed, or did you reball it? Where did you buy it? What diode readings do you get at the big coils near the chip?
